Describing ARMA Models

  • An autoregressive moving average (or ARMA) model is a model combining the autoregressive model and moving average model together

  • We typically denote an autoregressive model as the following:

    AR(p)AR(p)AR(p)
    • Where ppp is the number of lags included in the model

  • We typically denote a moving average model as the following:

    MA(k)MA(k)MA(k)
    • Where kkk is the order of lags included in the model

  • Therefore, we typically denote an ARMA model as the following:

    ARMA(p,k)ARMA(p, k)ARMA(p,k)
    • Where ppp refers to the number of lags from the autoregressive model
    • Where kkk refers to the order from the moving average model

  • Mathematically, we typically represent an ARMA model as the following:

    • Where the AR component is represented by β0+β1st−1\beta_{0} + \beta_{1}s_{t-1}β0​+β1​st−1​
    • Where the MA component is represented by θ1ϵt−1\theta_{1}\epsilon_{t-1}θ1​ϵt−1​

Differences Between AR and MA Models

  • The AR terms represent the lagged values sts_{t}st​
  • The MA terms represent the lagged errors ϵt\epsilon_{t}ϵt​ of sts_{t}st​
  • The primary difference between an AR and MA model is based on the correlation between time series objects at different time points
  • Specifically, the correlation between sts_{t}st​ and st−rs_{t-r}st−r​ is always zero as rrr grows larger in an MA model
  • This directly comes from the fact that covariance between sts_{t}st​ and st−rs_{t-r}st−r​ is zero for MA models
  • However, the correlation of sts_{t}st​ and st−rs_{t-r}st−r​ gradually declines as rrr grows larger in an AR model
  • This difference gets exploited irrespective of having the AR model or MA model
  • The correlation plot can give us the order of MA model

  • If we build an ARMA(1,1)ARMA(1,1)ARMA(1,1) model, then we would represent it as the following:

  • If we build an ARMA(2,1)ARMA(2,1)ARMA(2,1) model, then we would represent it as the following:

  • If we build an ARMA(1,2)ARMA(1,2)ARMA(1,2) model, then we would represent it as the following:
